children.value: Apollo Server needs to know how to populate data for every field in your schema so that it can respond to requests for that data. To accomplish this, it uses resolvers.
A resolver is a function that's responsible for populating the data for a single field in your schema.
It can populate that data in any way you define, such as by fetching data from a back-end database or a third-party API.
If you don't define a resolver for a particular field, Apollo Server automatically defines a

Each resolver function belongs to whichever type its corresponding field belongs to.

of that object (if it didn't, there would be no reason to include the object in the query). A query always "bottoms out" on fields that return a

Because of this rule, whenever Apollo Server
a field that returns an object type, it always then resolves one or more fields of that object. Those subfields might in turn
contain object types. Depending on your schema, this object-field pattern can continue to an arbitrary depth, creating what's called a

Resolver functions are passed four arguments:
You can use any name for each argument in your code, but the Apollo docs use these names as a convention. Instead of
, it's also common to use the parent type's name or
The return value of the resolver for this field's parent (i.e., the previous resolver in the
For resolvers of top-level fields with no parent (such as fields of
), this value is obtained from the
An object that contains all GraphQL arguments provided for this field.

An object shared across all resolvers that are executing for a particular operation. Use this to share per-operation state, including authentication information, dataloader instances, and anything else to track across resolvers.
Contains information about the operation's execution state, including the field name, the path to the field from the root, and more.
Its core fields are listed in the
. Apollo Server extends it with a
argument is useful for passing things that any resolver might need, like
, database connections, and custom fetch functions. If you're using
across resolvers, you can attach them to the
Resolvers should never destructively modify the
This ensures consistency across all resolvers and prevents unexpected errors.
constructor. This function is called with every request, so you can customize the context based on each request's details (such as HTTP headers).
This example assumes you're using either the
package, both of which use Express. The fields of the object passed to your
function might differ if you're using middleware besides Express.
See the API reference for details.
For more information on middleware in general, see
Context initialization can be asynchronous, allowing database connections and other operations to complete:
A resolver function's return value is treated differently by Apollo Server depending on its type:
A resolver can return a single value or an object, as shown in
. This return value is passed down to any nested resolvers via the
Return an array if and only if your schema indicates that the resolver's associated field contains a list.
After you return an array, Apollo Server executes nested resolvers for each item in the array.
Indicates that the value for the field could not be found.
If your schema indicates that this resolver's field is nullable, then the operation result has a
nullable, Apollo Server sets the field's
. If necessary, this process continues up the resolver chain until it reaches a field that
nullable. This ensures that a response never includes a
value for a non-nullable field. When this happens, the response's
property will be populated with relevant errors concerning the nullability of that field.
Resolvers often perform asynchronous actions, such as fetching from a database or back-end API. To support this, a resolver can return a promise that resolves to any other supported return type.
If you don't define a resolver for a particular schema field, Apollo Server defines a default resolver for it.

There are GraphQL types that enable you to define a field that returns one of multiple possible object types (i.e.,
). To resolve a field that can return different object types, you must define a
type of object is being returned.

As with all code, a resolver's performance depends on its logic. It's important to understand which of your schema's fields are computationally expensive or otherwise slow to resolve, so that you can either improve their performance or make sure you only query them when necessary.
integrates directly with Apollo Server to provide field-level metrics that help you understand the performance of your graph over time. For more information, see
